title: Chinese AI Company SenseTime Delays IPO as U.S. Imposes Investment Ban
summary: Treasury Department puts SenseTime on blacklist of Chinese companies that support China's military. Chinese artificial-intelligence company SenseTime Group Inc. is trying to keep its initial public offering alive, according to a person familiar with the matter, as the Biden administration adds the company to a blacklist that will ban American investors from buying its shares.

title: Paul Simon Tells the Stories Behind His Songs
summary: In a new audiobook, the singer/songwriter explores the creative process that led to 'The Boxer,' 'Graceland' and other classics. Paul Simon is adamant that he has no desire to write a memoir. He was intrigued, however, when the writer Malcolm Gladwell approached him with a different idea: to record an audiobook exploring his creative process as one of the world's most popular and prolific singer-songwriters. "The idea of discussing my music in an audio forum was attractive because I had never done that before," Mr. Simon, 80, said in a recent phone interview. "It's always in prose, which never captures what's going on in my musical thinking. The audio gives me the opportunity to demonstrate what I'm thinking, what influenced me, the choices that I make."

title: London Appeals Court Throws Out Conviction of Former Unaoil Executive
summary: In a rebuff to the U.K.'s Serious Fraud Office, the court said the agency's interactions with a private investigator protecting his own clients were 'wholly inappropriate'. A London appeals court has overturned the bribery conviction of a former Unaoil Group manager after finding that the U.K.'s Serious Fraud Office committed a "serious failure" in refusing to turn over evidence that would have helped him at trial.

title: U.S.-China Frictions Undercut Efforts to Settle Global Trade Disputes
summary: Washington and Beijing accuse each other of not abiding by World Trade Organization commitments, hindering the body's enforcement ability. WASHINGTON-Rising tensions between the U.S. and China are hampering efforts by members of the World Trade Organization to repair its ability to settle international trade disputes.

title: Dueling Accounts Emerge Over 'Rust' Set Fatal Shooting
summary: Key people of interest to investigators are putting forth diverging stories in interviews and lawsuits. Conflicting narratives have emerged from the cast and crew of the film "Rust" about what led to a fatal shooting on the set.

title: Truck in Fatal Crash Was Packed With Over 160 Migrants
summary: Smugglers said to cram people into tractor-trailers to avoid increased inspections of passenger buses on way to U.S.. MEXICO CITY-Smugglers have been packing U.S.-bound migrants into trucks such as the one in the fatal crash that killed dozens in southern Mexico to avoid stepped-up inspections of passenger buses, human-rights workers said.

title: AMC Shares Fall After CEO, CFO Sell Stock
summary: Sale generated $10.2 million for the movie-theater chain executives. Shares in AMC Entertainment Holdings Inc. fell more than 10% in trading on Friday after the chief executive officer and chief financial officer sold all or most of their currently vested interest in the company.

title: No Rules for Progressive Radicals
summary: Biden appointees try to stage a coup against the director of the FDIC on bank mergers.. Progressives are breaking institutional norms left and right to impose their agenda. On Thursday Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) Director Rohit Chopra went so far as to attempt a de facto coup against Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) Chair Jelena McWilliams, a Trump appointee.

title: The Supreme Court's Abortion Standing
summary: The merits of the Texas law weren't at issue, and the majority is right to block most pre-enforcement federal lawsuits.. The Supreme Court ruled Friday in a case involving S.B.8, the Texas law that bans abortions at around six weeks. But despite all the alarms, this opinion had nothing to do with the merits of the law or the right to abortion. The issue was legal standing. Credit the majority opinion by Justice Neil Gorsuch for refusing to rip up old doctrines to create some for-abortion-only exception.

title: Congress's Message to Biden on Defense
summary: The House overrules the Pentagon's after-inflation budget cut.. The House passed the annual National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) this week, 363-70, and the press is focusing on cultural issues like tweaks to the military's justice system and the defeated proposal to draft women. But the bigger story is that Congress delivered a bipartisan rebuke to the utterly unrealistic defense budget the Biden Administration released earlier this year.

title: Invading Ukraine Is a Trap for Vladimir Putin
summary: Russia can't be an empire without it, but it can't even be a great power if it overreaches.. Russia has stepped up its belligerence toward Ukraine, with troop movements, frequent attacks through state propaganda channels and direct threats from Russian leadership. The likelihood of a major European war is at its highest since the end of the Cold War.

title: The U.S. Sanctions Everybody but Putin
summary: Western governments still shrink from truth-telling because it might destabilize his regime.. Economic sanctions don't work, the truism goes, but sanctions are good at what they're supposed to do, imposing a cost for unwelcome behavior. A Vladimir Putin wouldn't act as he does if he weren't willing to pay the price, but the U.S. and its allies are still better off making him pay it.

title: The Bourbon Boom Puts Rural Kentucky Back on the Map
summary: A revival of interest in 'America's native spirit' is undoing Prohibition's economic damage.. Every era has its favorite alcohol. Gin was America's drink of choice in the early 20th century. At midcentury the country went crazy for vodka. This is the golden age of bourbon whiskey. More than 28 million cases of American whiskey-that is, bourbon and rye-were sold in the U.S. in 2020, yielding $4.3 billion in revenue for distillers.

title: Instacart President to Depart After Short Stint at Company
summary: The executive will leave the company at the end of this year. Instacart Inc. said its president, Carolyn Everson, will leave the food-delivery company at the end of this year, about four months after she joined from Facebook , marking the second high-profile departure in recent months ahead of a possible public offering.

title: Notable & Quotable: Checking Covid 'Facts'
summary: 'Claims that the 1963 movie 'Omicron' predicted the evolution of the latest variant strain of SARS-CoV-2 are false.'. From a Dec. 3 Reuters "fact check":

title: Supreme Court Rules Abortion Clinics Can Challenge Texas Law
summary: State law remains in effect for now; Texas has banned procedure after about six weeks of pregnancy. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court on Friday gave abortion providers a narrow legal path to challenge Texas' ban on ending pregnancies after six weeks, but the splintered ruling left the law in effect for now and made any rapid resumption of such abortions in the state unlikely.

title: David Bowie's 'Hunky Dory' at 50
summary: The hit-filled album marked a major turning point in the star's career and remains as fresh today as it was at its release a half-century ago..

title: Out of Many, One Work
summary: In Alfred Schnittke's Concerto for Piano and String Orchestra, the composer veers from Minimalist lyricism to Chopin-like piano writing to brief jazz riffs to atonality.

title: GM Plans $3 Billion for Electric-Vehicle Projects in Michigan
summary: Auto maker to convert suburban Detroit factory for electric trucks and plans battery-cell factory with LG. General Motors Co. plans to invest more than $3 billion to make electric vehicles in Michigan, people familiar with the matter said, a potential win for the car maker's home state after recent commitments of auto projects to Southern states.

title: Starbucks, Tyson Foods, GM: Stocks That Defined the Week
summary: Here are seven major companies whose stocks moved on the week's news. Royal Caribbean Group

title: Stocks Finish Higher After Inflation Nears 40-Year High
summary: Record high for S&P 500; Inflation data could influence Federal Reserve's timeline for reducing stimulus. U.S. stocks finished the week higher after fresh inflation data raised investors' hopes that price increases may be nearing a peak.

title: Starbucks Union Vote in Buffalo Energizes Labor Leaders
summary: Union officials say push will help fuel broader organizing movement; others say it is too small to make a difference. Starbucks Corp. workers may have voted as of now to unionize only a single store in the Buffalo, N.Y., area, but union leaders say the one win and the workers' organizing efforts will energize similar pushes across the country.

title: Prosecution Rests in Ghislaine Maxwell Trial
summary: Fourth accuser describes meeting British socialite at Jeffrey Epstein's New Mexico ranch. Federal prosecutors wrapped up their sex-trafficking case against Ghislaine Maxwell Friday afternoon after a fourth accuser testified that when she was 16 years old, the British socialite touched her breasts during a massage at Jeffrey Epstein's New Mexico ranch.

title: Democrats Confront Inflation, Cost Worries on $2 Trillion Plan
summary: Republicans say bill will cost more than advertised, hurt economy; Democratic leaders and Treasury's Yellen dispute that view.

title: Omicron Covid-19 Cases in U.S. Mostly Mild So Far, Data Show
summary: Report on 43 patients, most of whom were fully vaccinated, adds to early picture of variant's transmissibility, virulence. The Omicron variant of Covid-19 has so far caused mostly mild cases of Covid-19 in a small group of largely vaccinated people in the U.S., federal data show.

title: Building Back Bitter
summary: Inflation hits a 39-year high as Biden continues to demand another federal spending surge.. Consumers and workers are taking a beating as Washington fails to maintain the value of our currency.

title: Oil Price Swings Scramble Inflation Outlook
summary: Decline in crude prices has played out in lower bond-market bets on inflation. A loss of momentum in oil markets has prompted investors and traders to dial down bets on how fast inflation will run in the coming years.

title: What to Read This Week
summary: We hear from 50 voices in politics, business and the arts about their year in reading. Plus, our columnists on the best books of 2021 and more..

title: How Do You Expand Your House Without Ruining it? Build Another One.
summary: Resume Subscription. When Terry Mowers and Lindy Thorsen decided to move from Tennessee to their adobe vacation home in Marfa, Texas, they knew they would need more space. But they didn't want to disrupt the look of the minimalist, rectangular home, designed by the design studio Rael San Fratello.

title: Demaryius Thomas, Former Denver Broncos Player, Dead at 33
summary: The wide receiver retired in June after a decade in the NFL. Former star wide receiver Demaryius Thomas, who spent 10 seasons in the National Football League, was found dead Thursday in his Georgia home. He was 33.

title: Off of Work (Saturday Crossword, December 11)
Labyrinth (Saturday Variety Puzzle, December 11)
Treasury Yields Slip After Inflation Data Matches Expectations
summary: Core price index climbed 4.9% in November from a year earlier. U.S. government bond yields gave up overnight gains Friday after data showing the fastest inflation in decades reinforced investors' expectations for the economy to start slowing next year while the Federal Reserve tightens monetary policy.

title: Better.com CEO to Take Time Off After Zoom Firings
summary: Board hires outside firm to assess culture and leadership; finance chief to manage day-to-day decisions. Vishal Garg, chief executive of online mortgage lender Better.com, is taking time off effective immediately, the company said, a week after a video of him laying off hundreds of workers on a Zoom conference call was posted online and viewed by millions.

title: Who Read What in 2021
summary: Fifty voices from the worlds of politics, business, sports, literature and the arts share the books that they found essential in an extraordinary year.. It's a simple question-"What did you read this year?"-that unlocks a world of fascinating conversations. We asked leading lights in business, politics, writing and the arts to share their most memorable reading of 2021.

title: 'The Dawn of Everything' Review: Wrong From the Start
summary: A radical new critique argues our view of prehistoric humanity has been warped.. 'The Dawn of Everything" is a brainy and braggadocious book, styling itself-without a hint of modesty-as "a new history of humanity." A combative work that pushes a revisionist view of prehistory, it takes its fight to Jean-Jacques Rousseau and Thomas Hobbes, whose ideas on early man as a creature mired in a State of Nature it dismisses as pure fantasy. This is the anthropological equivalent of a tearing down of statues. Its authors are (the late) David Graeber and David Wengrow, professors, respectively, at the London School of Economics and University College London. Their book is a manifesto for early man, a bid to restore him to his "full humanity."

title: Volvo Hit by Cyber Theft of Intellectual Property
summary: Swedish car maker says cybersecurity breach could have impact on operations. BERLIN- Volvo Car AB, the Swedish car maker, said Friday that it was investigating a cybersecurity breach targeting systems that store research and development files and warned the hack could have an impact on the company's operations.

title: Abstractions Are Good for Goodness' Sake
summary: Santa Claus is an expression of the spirit of Christmas-just as ordinary mathematics reflects a deeper theoretical reality. Mathematician Eugenia Cheng explores the uses of math beyond the classroom. Read more columns here.

title: Michael Nesmith, the Monkee for All Seasons, Dies at 78
summary: Nesmith was a struggling singer-songwriter in 1966 when 'The Monkees' television debut turned him and fellow band members into overnight rock stars. LOS ANGELES-Michael Nesmith, the singer-songwriter, author, actor-director and entrepreneur who will likely be best remembered as the wool-hatted, guitar-strumming member of the made-for-television rock band The Monkees, has died at 78.

title: New York Gov. Kathy Hochul Imposes Mask Mandate for Indoor Places
summary: The state mandate for places without a vaccine mandate goes into effect early next week and will be re-evaluated in mid-January. New York Gov. Kathy Hochul said New Yorkers must wear masks in public indoor places unless those places require people to be vaccinated against Covid-19.

title: Federal Budget Deficit Widened in November on Increased Spending
summary: Monthly gap widens versus prior year, as government outlays rose at a faster rate than tax collection and other receipts. The federal government ran a $191 billion deficit during November, a bigger gap when compared with a year earlier, as additional revenue from payroll taxes and other receipts was more than offset by increased spending.

title: Will Outdoor Terraces and Chefs Lure You Back to the Office?
summary: Resume Subscription. Expensive air filtration systems to prevent the spread of Covid-19. Rooftop gardens irrigated by rainwater. A lunchtime menu from Michelin star chef Daniel Boulud.

title: Noonan and the Dark Consequences of Abortion Law
summary: Women, children and the soul are all implicated.. Regarding Peggy Noonan's "Will the Justices Let Go of Abortion?" (Declarations, Dec. 4): I was a nurse in the 1960s, before Roe v. Wade (1973). Women who were desperate for abortions got them. Those who could afford it flew to countries where it was safe and legal. Those who couldn't afford it went to underground abortionists, where many died. Others suffered complications so severe that they required hospital treatment. Overturning Roe would only hurt poor women.

title: Why English Flourishes as the Lingua Franca
summary: It isn't because of Anglo privilege or colonialist oppressiveness.. The world uses English as a lingua franca because it makes sense for millions of people ("The Downside of English's Dominance," Review, Nov. 27). My grandfather in India mandated the use of English in his house so his family could make progress. Many years later, my father scolded me for not learning a language before a military deployment to Europe. "Which one?" I responded. I was stationed in Italy with responsibilities in the Balkans and travel to Greece and Germany. On later overseas trips, I always found a way to communicate. In South Korea, price negotiation was done by typing numbers in a hand-held calculator.

title: The Chickasaw Nation Replies on Oklahoma Law
summary: Oklahoma's governor appears focused on recruiting national press to lay political siege to the court rather than engaging with tribal governments.. "How to Get Away With Manslaughter" (Review & Outlook, Dec. 4) uses provocative anecdotes to attack a Supreme Court ruling that reminded Oklahoma that U.S. treaties with tribal nations mean something. Oklahoma media offer a different perspective. "The observation of most media," editorialized the Tahlequah Daily Press, "is that tribes and feds are working at a steady pace to bring these cases to bear." The Tulsa World has suggested that curated outrage manifests "a bit of psychological denial" that "does nothing to make Oklahoma safer."

title: David Hockney's Adventures in Printmaking
summary: A new exhibition in Minneapolis explores the British painter's works on paper. When David Hockney visited New York for the first time in 1961, he had little money and a lot of ambition. Straight off the plane, the young British artist made his way to the Museum of Modern Art, where he showed a portfolio of his prints to the curator William S. Lieberman, who decided to buy them on the spot. The sale provided Mr. Hockney, now 84, with the money he needed to move to Los Angeles, where he would make some of his greatest paintings.

title: Attracting the World's Best: Vaccine Edition
summary: Scientists, venture capitalists and business leaders hailing from across the world came here and helped.. In "The Vast Promise of mRNA Technology" (op-ed, Dec. 4), Allysia Finley identifies messenger RNA's potential medical applications beyond Covid. Another important untold story is that the vaccines could not have been developed and applied without extensive international cooperation.

title: Chinese Chip Conglomerate Gains State-Backed Investment
summary: Two state-backed venture capital firms will help the heavily indebted company restructure its assets. Tsinghua Unigroup Co., the heavily indebted Chinese chip conglomerate, said a consortium led by two state-backed semiconductor venture-capital firms would become its strategic investor.

title: U.S. Wins Appeal in Assange Case, Bringing His Extradition Closer
summary: Lawyers for the WikiLeaks founder said they would seek permission to appeal the ruling at the U.K. Supreme Court. LONDON-The U.S. government won an appeal in its bid to extradite Julian Assange, clearing an important hurdle in Washington's yearslong battle to put the WikiLeaks founder on trial on spying charges.

title: Amazon Settles Suit Over Alleged Fake Cashmere Products
summary: Industry organization said it tested numerous products labeled as 100% cashmere by a U.S.-based store on the retailer's site and found they contained no cashmere. Amazon . com Inc. has settled a lawsuit over the sale of alleged fake cashmere products on its site, a cashmere industry organization said.

title: CNN Faces Prime-Time Uncertainty After Firing Chris Cuomo
summary: Don Lemon is among potential replacements in 9 p.m. hour, when network lags behind rivals. CNN's firing of anchor Chris Cuomo leaves a major void in its crucial 9 p.m. hour, at a time when the network is already struggling to reverse a decline in ratings.

title: U.K. Provides Clues on How Omicron Could Play Out in the U.S.
summary: Britain has more identified cases, strong Covid-19 surveillance and a population profile like America's. LONDON-The U.K. is emerging as a testing ground in the battle for dominance between the new Omicron variant of the coronavirus and Delta, the earlier strain that is currently driving most infections in the U.S. and Europe.

title: Paris in Winter: A Traveler's Guide to the Best New Museums and Art Exhibits
summary: The French capital is luring back visitors with brand-new art spaces and big-deal exhibits. Here, the museums and shows you don't want to miss.. AS CULTURAL CAPITALS go Paris has, for centuries, run ahead of the pack. That record-stymied during one of Europe's longest Covid-19 lockdowns-makes the current explosion of artistic attractions on view now extra gratifying. Two new museums have recently opened while one of the city's oldest has emerged from a four-year face-lift.

title: Omicron-the Belgian Metal Band-Makes the Best of Its Name
summary: Group is getting an unexpected chance at fame as new Covid-19 variant spreads. 'People were looking at me really weirdly.'. When Philippe Delhaute and Ignace Casier were working out the guitar parts for some new songs last week, they didn't expect their band's name to raise quite so many eyebrows.

title: At Least 55 Migrants Killed in Crash in Mexico
summary: Speeding truck was packed with more than 160 Central America migrants, mostly from Guatemala, who were being smuggled to the U.S.. MEXICO CITY-The out-of-control trailer truck that crashed into a pedestrian bridge in southern Mexico was packed with more than 160 migrants, of whom 55 were killed and at least 104 injured, Mexican authorities said.

title: U.S. Inflation Hits 39-Year High
summary: Consumer prices rose 0.8% in the month and 6.8% from a year ago. U.S. inflation reached a nearly four-decade high in November, as strong consumer demand collided with pandemic-related supply constraints.

title: American Manager Oversaw Digging of Channel Tunnel
summary: Longtime project manager, who has died at age 86, won Queen's gratitude after completion of 31-mile link; the 2012 Olympics were another story. Wherever people were gouging deeply into the earth or building massive structures on top of it, Jack K. Lemley seemed to turn up.

title: The Best Books of 2021: Mysteries
summary: Tom Nolan selects the best of the year in mystery and crime fiction..

title: The Best Books of 2021: Politics
summary: Barton Swaim revisits the best of a year in political argument and analysis.. Books on the early concerns for the nation, political battles over the high court and more from a year in reading.

title: The Best Books of 2021: Children's Books
summary: Meghan Cox Gurdon on her picks for the year, including picture books, middle-grade reading and books for young adults.. Our columnist selects the year's best reading for kids, from picture books to sophisticated works for older readers.

title: The Best Books of 2021: Science Fiction
summary: Tom Shippey picks his favorites from this year's crop of science fiction and fantasy..

title: China Shifts Back to Emphasizing Economic Stability
summary: Chinese leaders pledge to keep growth stable after government's policies to rein in risks have triggered a sharp economic slowdown. HONG KONG-China shifted its focus back to keeping growth stable as a string of policies to curb debt and speculation have triggered a sharp economic slowdown, particularly in the property market.

title: The Defenders: Three Books on the Science of Immunity
summary: The body has a complex system to block invaders. Scientists have learned how to join the fight.. In 1796, an English country doctor named Edward Jenner had a brainstorm. At the time, smallpox was a scourge that killed 30% of those it infected, and left many survivors with disfiguring scars. There was an unsavory preventive measure, known as variolation, which called for powder from a dried-up smallpox scab to be either inhaled or rubbed into a cut in the skin. This usually led to mild infection with lasting immunity, but also occasionally caused deaths from full-blown smallpox. As John S. Tregoning notes in "Infectious" this wasn't overly surprising, with 'the scab' not being a precise unit of measurement."

title: 'The Greek Revolution' Review: Hellenism and Heroism
summary: A cause célèbre in its day, the Greek fight for independence inspired revolutionaries across Europe.. Pandemic is a Greek word, but in 2021 the Greeks have had more than a virus to commemorate. This year marks the bicentennial of their revolution against the Ottoman Empire, a decadelong war in which a small population fought against overwhelming odds to become the first relatively independent European nation to emerge in the 19th century. As Mark Mazower explains in "The Greek Revolution: 1821 and the Making of Modern Europe"-his superb new history of the rebellion and its broader implications-the uprising "came near the end of a half century of revolution. This epoch of global transformation had begun with the United States successfully shaking off colonial power and it continued with the French overthrow of their monarchy and Haiti's bid for freedom. As the Greeks rose up, the Spanish colonies in South America were fighting for independence, and much of southern Europe was in turmoil." Far from being a minor event in a marginal country, the Greek Revolution galvanized the 19th century's nationalist movements. That it very nearly failed provides Mr. Mazower with a compelling story-full of conflicting characters, rivalries, massacres, betrayals, enslavements-all of which he narrates with earned authority and exceptional power.

title: 'John Williams: Collected Novels' Review: A Literary Lazarus
summary: The author of 'Stoner' and 'Augustus' now has the readers he couldn't find in his lifetime.. John Williams never aspired to be a writer for his times. Many novelists do-just look at Williams's contemporaries: Jack Kerouac, Kurt Vonnegut (both born in the same year as Williams, 1922), James Baldwin, Norman Mailer; each unlike the others but all engaged with the day-to-day turbulence of American life. By contrast, Williams planted each of his three major novels in different corner of the past. The first, "Butcher's Crossing" (1960), enters the Old West in the 1870s, finding it not so much wild as dreary and brutal. The last of the trio, "Augustus," set in Rome after the assassination of Julius Caesar in 44 B.C., is a tour de force of imaginative reconstruction. The meticulously structured epistolary novel was the most successful of Williams's books during his lifetime. It shared the National Book Award with John Barth's "Chimera" in 1973.

title: Musk Tweets (in Jest?) That He Might Quit His Jobs
summary: Tesla and SpaceX CEO's tweet comes days after he said he was 'aspirationally funny'. Tesla Inc. and SpaceX Chief Executive Elon Musk late Thursday said he might quit his jobs, without providing details about which positions he might relinquish or how serious he was about changing roles.

title: The Mysterious Lady: Two Books on Greta Garbo
summary: She arrived in Hollywood as an outsider and built her global appeal on a carefully maintained mystique.. The first biography of Greta Garbo was published in America in 1931, when the Swedish film star was 26. Piles of other books have followed, with no sign of letting up even now, more than three decades after her death. The writer Robert Dance remarks that only Charlie Chaplin rivals Garbo as the most frequent subject of books about actors in early Hollywood.

title: Tom Ford on Eating Sugary Treats for Breakfast
summary: The provocative, perfection-driven fashion designer on turning 60, publishing a new book and adjusting to being a single father following the loss of his husband, Richard Buckley.. Tom Ford says he never thinks about his legacy. "I'm not someone who often looks back," says the fashion designer, 60. "When I finish something, I push it back and I move on to the next thing."

title: The Best Gluten-Free Holiday Baking Recipes
summary: With the help of a chemist, we've come up with festive recipes for cakes, cookies and an apple frangipane galette that are all delicious and gluten-free.. MY GO-TO dessert when baking for someone avoiding gluten has always been a nut torte. This type of flourless cake gets its structure from nut flours and eggs, and takes very well to chocolate. But one recent day, with a bag of freshly picked apples and a gluten-sensitive dinner guest on the way, I decided to brave a gluten-free galette. While most recipes simply call for substituting wheat flour with a wheat-free flour blend, I sensed that this approach would yield limited success.

title: Computers Revolutionized Chess. Magnus Carlsen Wins by Being Human.
summary: Chess engines were supposed to make classical chess more predictable. Instead, they made the most inventive player of all time more creative.. The World Chess Championship was already a week old when something stunning happened in Game 6: after nearly eight hours of play last Friday, someone actually won.

title: Norman Podhoretz on the Spiritual War for America
summary: The left wants to win, he says, but 'I'm not sure anymore what our side wants.' That's a big part of what drew him to Trump.. There was a time-roughly from the mid-1960s to the rise of Donald Trump in 2015-when the American right was more or less definable. No more. Major political parties are always riven by internal disputes, but even during George W. Bush's second term, at the nadir of the Iraq war, the Republican coalition seemed to hang together better than it has these past six years. Mr. Trump's candidacy was a sign of that fracturing rather than its cause, but his presidency wasn't marked by unity in the GOP.

title: Five Best: Books on Pandemics, Pathogens and Public Health
summary: Selected by television writer-producer and public-health journalist Seth Freeman.. By John M. Barry (2004)

title: Is MIT's Research Helping the Chinese Military?
summary: My concerns about how Beijing might be using our findings were dismissed as racist and political.. I was thrilled when I joined the board of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's McGovern Institute for Brain Research seven years ago. But last week I resigned. I'm no longer confident the institute can ethically push the boundaries of science for the good of humanity while working with institutions beholden to the regime in China.

title: Meet the Kidd Who Goes Toe to Toe With Warren Buffett
summary: Patience, concentration and courage have allowed Wilmot Kidd to rack up one of the greatest long-term track records in the history of investing. He's a model for how to think about, and practice, intelligent investing.. The typical stock fund manager is a sheep in wolf's clothing: passively mimicking the market, with only a few small and timid active bets.

title: Inflation's Warm-Up Act
summary: Just because recent high-inflation readings probably won't persist doesn't mean prices won't keep rising at a faster clip than before the pandemic. Inflation will probably cool next year, but it may still be plenty warm.

title: Venezuela's Fatal Embrace of Cuba
summary: Resume Subscription. In the first half of 2019, Venezuela began to suffer gasoline shortages. This, on its face, was preposterous. The nation had the world's largest proven oil reserves-its refineries boasted the capacity to supply the country's needs many times over. Yet drivers up and down the land found themselves waiting days on end in lines outside gas stations, bringing to mind the old joke about how if communists took over the Sahara it would run out of sand.

title: The New Working Vacation
summary: Resume Subscription. After working long hours on tight deadlines for a big project as a landscape designer in Pittsburgh, Daryn Cassada was burned out. So her boss paid for a week away at a wellness resort in Hilton Head, S.C. It wasn't exactly a vacation, but it wasn't a work trip either.

title: (Spoilers Ahead) Peloton: Don't Blame Us for What Happened in 'And Just Like That...'
summary: Company got good product placement in the first episode of the 'Sex and the City' revival, but was just as surprised as viewers at the plotline. Spoiler alert: Mr. Big dies in the "Sex and the City" reboot.

title: Home Exercise Equipment No Longer Pumped Up
summary: Discounted pair of Bowflex dumbbells shows that demand for home exercise equipment has returned to normal. It might seem like Mr. Big's death by Peloton in the first episode of "Sex and the City" reboot was the straw that broke the camel's back for home fitness. Turns out, it was already on ice.

title: Waukesha's Businesses Recovering After Christmas Parade Attack
summary: Resume Subscription. WAUKESHA, Wis.-Business is picking up in Waukesha's historic downtown, as residents here hope to help the district rebound after a driver sped through an annual Christmas parade, killing six and leaving dozens injured last month.

title: Sera Gamble, the Co-Creator of 'You,' on Where the TV Business Goes From Here
summary: Among the predictions: More global shows, the algorithm as boss, scared Suits and content overload. At the height of Los Angeles' brutal January Covid outbreak, I sat in my kitchen at 1 a.m., drinking coffee to stay alert for the on-set rehearsal being livestreamed to my iPad. As I texted with the director, ambulance sirens announced another patient headed to an overwhelmed ER.

title: Where Will SPACs Be in Five Years?
summary: We posed that question to six experts. The consensus: They will still be around, but different.. It has been a wild year for special-purpose acquisition companies. Known as SPACs, these are shell companies that raise money and list shares on a stock exchange with the aim of merging with a private company.

title: Leaking Hull, Hazardous Cargo: Aboard a Stranded Ship No One Would Help
summary: Resume Subscription. LIMASSOL, Cyprus-The cargo ship laden with 3,000 tons of flammable sulfur was stranded off the coast of Somalia and taking on water.

title: Reluctant Advertising Woman Reached Top of Her Trade
summary: Laurel Cutler, who has died at age 94, was a Wellesley philosophy major who wanted to write novels but ended up advising top executives at the likes of Chrysler and Campbell Soup. Laurel Cutler, a philosophy major at Wellesley College, briefly tried to launch herself as a novelist in the 1940s. Ms. Cutler was, as she put it later, determined never to "prostitute my art for money."

title: Everybody Now Wants Supply Chains to Be 'Resilient.' That Won't Be Easy-or Likely.
summary: Despite the current turmoil, memories will fade, and economics will trump concerns about national vulnerabilities. Supply chains as front-page news? That would have seemed unlikely-until the pandemic exposed many of the vulnerabilities in the far-flung networks that connect manufacturers, suppliers and buyers around the globe.

title: Why Do Prices Keep Going Up and What's the Cause of Inflation?
summary: Inflation accelerated again last month, with the consumer-price index rising at a 39-year high rate of 6.8%, as heavy demand and supply shortages persist. U.S. inflation is at its highest rate in nearly four decades this fall, reaching 6.8% in November from a year ago. Consumers are seeing prices rise sharply for a variety of goods and services because of persistent supply and labor shortages and strong demand.

title: Chewy, Oracle, Broadcom, Moderna, Nubank: What to Watch in the Stock Market Today
summary: Oracle's quarterly results beat forecasts; Nubank was extending gains after its IPO. Wall Street stock indexes swung higher after fresh data showed that U.S. inflation hit a 39-year high of 6.8% last month. Here's what we're watching in Friday's trading action:

title: Iran Bets Its Economy Will Hold as It Takes Tough Stance on Nuclear Program
summary: Negotiators are in Vienna this week to find a breakthrough in stalled talks to revive the 2015 nuclear deal. TEHRAN-U.S. sanctions on Iran have battered the country's economy, causing unemployment to soar and its currency to plummet, which has helped stoke public unrest in recent years.

title: Andrea Orcel Wins Case Against Santander
summary: Santander must pay executive over $75 million for failing to follow through on a deal to hire him as CEO. A Spanish judge ruled that Banco Santander SA must pay Andrea Orcel more than $75 million for reneging on a promise to name him chief executive, in the latest twist in a fight between two of Europe's most powerful bankers.

title: The Appeal of Artists Who Won Fame After Death
summary: Some of the greatest names in the arts were unknown in their lifetimes, offering the hope that genius is bound to triumph in the end. With her men's coats and floppy hats, her hair and cheeks shiny with Vaseline, Vivian Maier was a conspicuous figure on Chicago's North Shore before she died in 2009 at age 83. Locals gave her an array of nicknames-Bird Lady, Army Boots, Wicked Witch-never realizing that the old woman who haunted the same park bench nearly every day would one day be deemed an artistic genius.

title: Cramped Home Workouts? 4 Solutions Smaller than a Yoga Mat
summary: New resistance-training devices fit a weight room's worth of equipment into any corner. Here, our top recommendations.. Andrea Chapman , a marketing manager in San Diego, Calif., hadn't been to a proper gym in nearly six months when she finally accepted that her "hiatus" was more permanent. "I had no choice but to do exercises at home, which I wasn't used to, and that pushed me to finally purchase equipment," she said. In September 2020, she bought herself a Zeno Workout Bench. The compact gym, which enables her to do more than 75 different exercises using resistance bands, quickly made up for the loss of her studio workouts. "I love its versatility."

title: High Inflation Keeps Pressure on Fed to Dial Back Stimulus Faster
summary: Deliberations at next week's policy meeting could influence how soon the central bank raises interest rates. The latest strong inflation report strengthens the case for Federal Reserve officials to agree next week to accelerate the wind-down of their stimulus efforts, clearing the way for them to potentially lift interest rates in the spring.

title: U.S.-Trained Somali Commandos Suspend Islamic State Fight Amid Political Turmoil
summary: With American forces gone, a skirmish breaks out over one of Somalia's elite counterterrorism units. NAIROBI-A Somali commando unit trained by Central Intelligence Agency operatives and U.S. Navy SEALs has become so entangled in local political power struggles that it has ceased operations against the Islamist militants it was created to fight.

title: Steven Spielberg Made 'West Side Story' Without Subtitles, Says Translating Spanish Would Be 'Disrespectful'
summary: Resume Subscription. Maria and her brother Bernardo switch repeatedly between English and Spanish as they bicker in the new "West Side Story." Bernardo's girlfriend Anita insists, "Everybody, speak English!"

title: Defense Intelligence Agency Expected to Lead Military's Use of 'Open Source' Data
summary: Directive would place agency in charge of setting policy for intelligence gleaned from social-media and commercial-data troves. The Defense Department is expected to name the Defense Intelligence Agency as its lead agency for "open-source" intelligence, according to U.S. officials, highlighting the growing importance of unclassified information drawn from social media, online material and commercial data sources in modern military operations.

title: The Outcome of This Formula One Rivalry May Be Just a Crash Away
summary: Lewis Hamilton and Max Verstappen enter Sunday's final race of the season level on points. But Verstappen knows that he would be world champion if neither driver finishes..

title: Travel After Covid Lockdowns: In Search of Wonder
summary: Resume Subscription. Just as the coronavirus began to seep into our consciousness early last year, I found myself sailing around Antarctica. I'm generally an urban creature, and having enjoyed watching 1.5 million penguins once in Patagonia, and spending midwinter weeks in Alaska, gazing out over miles of snow, I hadn't been so excited in advance. But nothing I'd seen had prepared me for the blue-green icebergs, as tall as five-story buildings, among which I drifted one blue midsummer morning. For the thousand shades of silver, gray and pure white that surrounded me on every side. For the shocking absence of any sound, or sight of human habitation.

title: Covid-19 Patients Benefit From Improved Screening, Treatment of Blood Clots
summary: Doctors focus on early diagnosis of the potentially dangerous condition. Edward Hatfield didn't think he had any symptoms of blood clotting when he sought emergency care for Covid-19 in August. He experienced breathing difficulty and a falling oxygen level.

title: Mercedes-Benz Faces a Bumpier Road Than Freightliner
summary: Daimler spun out its heavy-truck business from its better-known car manufacturer, giving investors the choice which to own. Mercedes-Benz cars promise a thrilling ride, but investors may be safer in a Freightliner rig.

title: Colorful Gemstones: The New Way to Wear Grande-Dame Jewelry
summary: Brilliant gems and big diamonds worn in adventurous ways show that luxurious jewelry can rock your world. New ways to style major statement pieces.. Forget ballgowns and fur coats-this season's offerings of wildly imaginative high and fine jewelry in rainbow hues beg to be paired, with say, an edgy braided-leather tank top or a spaghetti-strap Saint Laurent by Anthony Vaccarello dress. This ultra-high end of the jewelry market from names such as Cartier, Harry Winston, Dior, Louis Vuitton and Graff is known for showstopping gems at showstopping prices, often focusing on classical concepts and settings. (Read: big, bright diamonds in carefully crafted floral or sleek designs).

title: Chewy Needs to Teach Itself More Tricks
summary: The pet boom is waning, and so is investors' love for Chewy. Not unlike pandemic pets whose human companions are rediscovering the outside world, Chewy is having a harder time keeping its shareholders' full attention.

title: Private Equity Faces Paying for Portfolio Company Misdeeds
summary: Private-equity firms are more often facing charges over the conduct of the companies they own, a break from precedent.

title: Southern California's Container-Ship Backlog Moves Farther Out to Sea
summary: Authorities say strong winds and rough seas have forced them to keep ships farther apart and away from the ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach. The backup of container ships waiting to enter the nation's busiest port complex isn't letting up. But it has moved farther from shore.

title: That Big Office Building? It's an E-Commerce Warehouse Now.
summary: More companies are making remote work permanent, forcing developers to convert old office buildings into warehouses, apartments and other uses. Allstate Corp.'s suburban campus outside Chicago, with its interconnected buildings, manicured grounds and acres of parking, represented a new vision for the U.S. office when it opened in 1967. That vision is now dead.

title: As China's Economy Falters, the Rest of World Looks Resilient
summary: China's shaky economy, and teetering property giants like Evergrande, are shaping up as major concerns for 2022. A full-scale meltdown may be avoided, however-if only just.. Chinese history plays out in cycles, or so goes the well-worn cliché. Whether or not that is true, it is undeniable that five years after the last major downturn, the specter of another Chinese property crash-and associated financial turbulence-is once again tormenting global markets.

title: Omicron Disrupts Government Plans to Lure Migrant Workers as Labor Shortages Bite
summary: Variant is a blow to efforts to attract more migrant workers amid a collapse in immigration and serious labor shortages. The arrival of the Omicron variant of the coronavirus is a blow for governments around the world that were banking on foreign workers to help ease labor shortages pinching their economies.

title: China Pushes Back Against Yuan Rally
summary: The surge is unusual because it comes while the dollar is also gaining ground. The yuan has soared to multiyear highs against the dollar and other major currencies, reflecting strong demand for China's exports and its financial assets, and prompting some pushback from the country's central bank.

title: Making Year-End Donations? Get the Most Tax Bang for Your Charity Buck
summary: New rules for 2021 provide extra tax deductions for charitable giving. But some older rules are worth reviewing too. Here are charitable-deduction strategies to consider before the year ends.. Dec. 31 is the last day for individuals to make tax-deductible charitable donations for 2021.

title: Sky-High Vaccination Rates, Zero Taxes Create Boomtown
summary: Resume Subscription. DUBAI-This city-state of skyscrapers and Persian Gulf beaches is emerging as a pandemic boomtown, drawing in the ultrarich, entrepreneurs and tourists with open-border policies, high levels of vaccination and low Covid-19 infection rates.

title: Nicaragua Breaks Off Ties With Taiwan in Favor of Beijing
summary: The Central American country's decision cuts Taiwan's diplomatic partners to 14 as the island pushes to boost its global stature. TAIPEI-Nicaragua has cut diplomatic ties with Taiwan in favor of China, denting the democratically self-ruled island's effort to expand its international profile amid opposition from Beijing.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.
